page.title: 11HOUSES
page.content: RETTENDON OLD HALL This is one of the oldest houses surviving in the village. In 1743 the house was restored, but it is much older. A person called Colonel Pritchard lived there before Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence-Jones. In Mrs. Lawrence-Jones' garden there are lots of trees; walnut trees, a fig tree, an apple tree and a plum tree. There is a well, half built, by one of their sons. RETTENDON HOUSE Lady Telford has got 15 rooms in her house & the flat that is next door to her. The garden is 200 metres long, approximately six and a half acres, there is a swimming pool in it. In Lady Telford's copse are ash, sycamore, limes, maple, sweet chestnut, lodge pole pine, one mature elm,and one young elm. She and Sir Robert planted the copse in 1975.
